Award.AwardTitle: III: Student Travel Fellowships for SIGIR Privacy-Preserving IR Workshop 2016

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
This National Science Foundation award funds Student Travel Fellowships for US students attending the 2016 Privacy-Preserving Information Retrieval (PIR) Workshop. The workshop is co-located with the ACM SIGIR Conference on Research and Development in Information Retrieval in Pisa, Italy. The Student Fellowships helps cover the travel costs for US students, making it possible for them to attend the workshop and discuss and disseminate their work. The workshop also provides an opportunity for them to interact with future national and international scientific collaborators.

The PIR Workshop brings together an interdisciplinary group of researchers and practitioners in Information Retrieval, Privacy and Security. Students benefit from not only the technical paper presentations, but also other activities such as talk from industry leaders, and panel/breakout sessions which pair information retrieval and privacy researchers together to discuss about emerging challenges across the two communities. These sessions provide students with an opportunity to learn the recent research developments in an emerging interdisciplinary field, while the informal settings of the breakouts also enable students to get critical yet encouraging feedback on their work from senior members of the community.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This National Science Foundation sponsored student travel grant has helped with US students to travel overseas to attend the 2016 Privacy-Preserving Information Retrieval Workshop co-located with the ACM SIGIR Conference on Research and Development in Information Retrieval (SIGIR). The 2016 workshop happened in Pisa, Italy, which was far and expensive for US students to travel to, however, the grant has greatly encouraged submissions and attendance in the workshop. The workshop also successfully brought together many experts from the research fields of both privacy and information retrieval, fostered lively and insightful discussions. Through an intense and rewarding full-day program, the students benefitted in a variety of interactions, including research paper presentations, poster sessions, keynote talks, panel discussions, and social events, with the experts in the fields. 

 

Privacy is a crucial research area which affects everyone’s life and protects people from potential privacy threats. Privacy-preserving data-related research has been studied in the past 10 years. However, its interaction with the Information Retrieval (IR) research is still relatively new. The goals of this series of workshops are (1) bringing together the two research fields, (2) yielding fruitful collaborations, and (3) foster research in the green field of privacy-preserving Information Retrieval, with the hope to encourage a new research paper session in the following year’s SIGIR main conference.

 

Outcome in terms of Intellectual Merit: 

 

 

Outcome 1: The Workshop has brought together an interdisciplinary group of researchers and practitioners in Information Retrieval, Privacy and Security. We targeted on three themes: differential privacy and IR dataset release, privacy in search and browsing, and privacy in social media.We solicited papers and presentations in the following topics: Differential Privacy for Information Retrieval, Query log anonymization, IR dataset release, Privacy preserving search/browsing, Privacy in social media, microblog, and people search, Evaluation for privacy-preserving IR, Leak of sensitive information in natural languages, Privacy in location-based services, recommender systems, and other IR works on mobile app, and Privacy preserving IR for healthcare and other domains. The authors, presenters, and participants, have produced papers and talks on “Differential Privacy in the Wild”, “Privacy Leakage through Innocent Content Sharing in Online Social Networks”, “Privacy-Preserving Inference of Social Relationships from Location Data”, “Private Information Retrieval from Encrypted Data”, and “ Releasing True Data with Formal Privacy Guarantees”. The materials are maintained online at https://privacypreservingir.org/pir16

 

 

Outcome 2: Students benefitted from not only the technical paper presentations, but also other activities such as talk from industry leaders, and panel/breakout sessions which pair information retrieval and privacy researchers together to discuss about emerging challenges across the two communities. The following experts participated in the workshop: Ashwin Machanavajjhala (Duke University; privacy), Carsten Eickhoff (ETH Zurich; IR), Cyrus Shahabi (University of Southern California; privacy), Li Xiong (Emory University; privacy); Murat Kantarcioglu (Purdue University; privacy), Frederik Armknecht (University of Mannheim; privacy), Doug Oard (University of Maryland College Park; IR); Charlie Clarke (University of Waterloo; IR), Ian Soboroff (National Institute of Standards and Technology; IR), and Grace Hui Yang (Georgetown University; IR). 

 

 

Outcome 3: A permanent website about “privacy-preserving information retrieval” research and related resources. It is located at https://privacypreservingir.org/. The PI and her team will continue their support to this resource website. 

 

 

Outcome in terms of Broader Impact: 

 

Outcome 1: This 2016 SIGIR workshop is the third Privacy Preserving IR Workshop organized for three years in a row since 2014 at ACM SIGIR, the premium conference for research in Information Retrieval and Web Search Engines. This student travel grant has helped the workshop increased its participation from 10 in SIGR 2015 to 30 in SGIR 2016, which was a significant boost in terms of number of participants. The long research papers presented in the workshop were all from student first-authors and were presented by the student authors. One of them is female computer science student. This grant promoted research in the joint field of privacy and IR to allow students working on this important yet understudied area. 

 

Outcome 2: The impact of the workshop has not limited to the workshop itself. We are very happy to announce that in the following year of ACM SIGIR 2017, a new privacy main research paper track appeared. Many of the SIGIR 2017 privacy-related papers have cited the SIGIR 2016 workshop that this grant sponsored and the papers published in this workshop. We believe  the sponsored SIGIR 2016 privacy preserving IR workshop has not only advanced research in this field within the United States but also world-wide.
